titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: An unpleasant fog lasted until past noon, then fine and much warmer. The frost has broken at last. Our proceedings began with the reading by the Archbishop of a terrible message from the Russian Archbishops, telling of the persecution to which the Church is subjected by the Bolshevists, who are violently suppressing Christianity wherever they go.
Then I resumed the debate on our relations with the Nonconformists
the 5 objections which Gore had advanced overnight. The discussion went on until after lunch, & then ended lamely in the appointment of another joint C
at our own request, both Gore & I were omitted
The Archbishop asked me to walk with him. He told me that
the Bishop of Zanzibar threatened a schism over my consecration, & that the matter w
probably come to a head in the next Lambeth Conference

I dined with Miss Mundella. Dorothea & Sir Robert Younger made up the party. We had much pleasant conversation. Y. told us that Finlay first heard of his dismissal from the Lord Chancellorship when he read in the newspapers that F. E. Smith had been appointed to succeed him.
This gives an ill impression of the Prime Minister's mode of treating his colleagues.
